text_run.content: This guide walks you through how to create and manage partitions in a collection.
A partition in Zilliz Cloud represents a sub-division of a collection. This functionality allows the physical storage of a collection to be divided into multiple parts, contributing to improved
performance by narrowing down the focus to a smaller subset of data rather than the entire collection.
Upon the creation of a collection, a default partition named
is automatically assigned. It's worth noting that you can create a maximum of 64 partitions within a collection.
For a comprehensive understanding of the relationships between clusters, collections, indexes, partitions, and entities, read
Zilliz Cloud introduces a feature called
, leveraging the underlying partitions to store entities based on specific field values. This feature facilitates the implementation of multi-tenancy, enhancing search performance. For details, read
It's important to note that when the
feature is on, Zilliz Cloud takes care of managing all partitions, relieving you of this responsibility.

The code snippet below repurposes the existing code to establish a connection to a Zilliz Cloud cluster and create a collection and its index separately. Consequently, the collection remains unloaded.

from pymilvus import MilvusClient

# 1. Connect to a cluster

# Replace CLUSTER_ENDPOINT and TOKEN with your own
client = MilvusClient(
    uri=CLUSTER_ENDPOINT, # Cluster endpoint obtained from the console
    token=TOKEN # An API key or a colon-separated cluster username and password
)

# 2. Set up the schema
schema = client.create_schema(
    enable_dynamic_field=True
)

# add the primary key
schema.add_field("id", DataType.INT64, is_primary=True, auto_id=True)

# add the vector field
schema.add_field("vector", DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR, dimension=768)


# 3. Create a collection
client.create_collection(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    schema=schema
)

# 4. Set up the index parameters
index_params = client.prepare_index_params()

# Add an index on the vector field.
index_params.add_index(
    field_name="vector",
    index_name="vector_idx",
    metric_type="COSINE",
    index_type="AUTOINDEX"
)

# 5. Create an index file
client.create_index(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    index_params=index_params
)
In the above code snippet, the index of the collection has been created separately, indicating that the collection is left unloaded upon creation.
Once a collection is ready, you can list its partitions.
The output of the above code snippet is a list of strings, stating the names of the partitions within the specified collection.
You can add more partitions to the collection. A collection can have up to 64 partitions.

client.create_partition(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_name="partitionA"
)

client.create_partition(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_name="partitionB"
)

res = client.list_partitions(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020"
)

# Output
#
The code snippet above creates a partition in a collection and lists the partitions of the collection.
You can also check the existence of a specific partition.
The code snippet above checks whether the collection
You can load and release specific partitions to make them available or unavailable for searches and queries.
To check the load status of a collection and its partitions, do as follows:

# Get load status
res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
)

# Ouptut
#
# Not Loaded
if at least one of its partitions has been loaded.
if none of its partitions has been loaded.
if at least one of its partitions is in the loading process.
To load all partitions of a collection, you can just call
. To load specific partitions of a collection, do as follows:

client.load_partitions(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_names="partitionA"
)

res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_name("partitionA")
)

# Output
#
To load multiple partitions at a time, do as follows:

client.load_partitions(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_names=["_default", "partitionA"]
)

res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
)

# Output
#
# Not Loaded

res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_name="_default"
)

# Output
#
To release all partitions of a collection, you can just call
. To release specific partitions of a collection, do as follows:

client.release_partitions(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_names="partitionA"
)

res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_name("partitionA")
)

# Output
#
To release multiple partitions at a time, do as follows:

client.release_partitions(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
    partition_names=["_default", "partitionA", "partitionB"]
)

res = client.get_load_status(
    collection_name="medium_articles_2020",
)

# Output
#
